data.meanings: to send back, turn back, reject, refuse, repel, revert, restore, give back, refer, give again, take again, repeat, retrace. maraddun - place where one returns. mardud - restored, averted. irtadda (vb. 8) - to return, turn again, be rendered. taradda (vb. 5) - to be agitated, move to and fro.
data.sentence: The word رُدُّوهَا comes from the root ر د د and is associated with the meanings: to send back, turn back, reject, refuse, repel, revert, restore, give back, refer, give again, take again, repeat, retrace. maraddun - place where one returns. mardud - restored, averted. irtadda (vb. 8) - to return, turn again, be rendered. taradda (vb. 5) - to be agitated, move to and fro.

data.meanings: begin/start to do something, to take to doing something, to set about, commence/initiate, continue uninterruptedly.
data.sentence: The word فَطَفِقَ comes from the root ط ف ق and is associated with the meanings: begin/start to do something, to take to doing something, to set about, commence/initiate, continue uninterruptedly.

data.meanings: to wipe/rub/stroke, passing one's hand over something, chosen/anointed, messiah
data.sentence: The word مَسْحًا comes from the root م س ح and is associated with the meanings: to wipe/rub/stroke, passing one's hand over something, chosen/anointed, messiah

data.meanings: to drive/impel/urge. yusaquna - they are driven or led. saiqun - driver. suq (pl. aswaq) - market, stem, leg, kashafat an saqaiha (27:44) is a well known Arabic idiom meaning to become prepared to meet the difficulty or to become perturbed/perplexed or taken aback, the literal meaning is "she uncovered and bared her shanks". yukshafu an saqin (68:42) means ther eis severe affliction and the truth laid here, it is indicative of a grievous and terrible calamity and difficulty. masaq - the act of driving.
data.sentence: The word بِالسُّوقِ comes from the root س و ق and is associated with the meanings: to drive/impel/urge. yusaquna - they are driven or led. saiqun - driver. suq (pl. aswaq) - market, stem, leg, kashafat an saqaiha (27:44) is a well known Arabic idiom meaning to become prepared to meet the difficulty or to become perturbed/perplexed or taken aback, the literal meaning is "she uncovered and bared her shanks". yukshafu an saqin (68:42) means ther eis severe affliction and the truth laid here, it is indicative of a grievous and terrible calamity and difficulty. masaq - the act of driving.

data.meanings: to be long-necked, become thin in the neck. ta'anaqa - to embrace. unuqun (pl. a'naq) neck, company (of men), trunk (of a tree), stalk (of a leaf or fruit), heads or chiefs of men, great ones. In 17:29 it is used as  a metaphorical phrase to mean: do not keep your hand stackled to your neck out of miserliness, do not be niggardly. In verse 17:13 unuqun is metaphorically used and refers to the principle that every action produces an effect which is "made to cling to a person" and that his deeds will be recorded in a Book and that their effect will be seen on the day of resurrection. "Clinging to the neck" indicates the inseparability of one thing from another, thus establishing the law of cause and effect.
data.sentence: The word وَالْأَعْنَاقِ comes from the root ع ن ق and is associated with the meanings: to be long-necked, become thin in the neck. ta'anaqa - to embrace. unuqun (pl. a'naq) neck, company (of men), trunk (of a tree), stalk (of a leaf or fruit), heads or chiefs of men, great ones. In 17:29 it is used as  a metaphorical phrase to mean: do not keep your hand stackled to your neck out of miserliness, do not be niggardly. In verse 17:13 unuqun is metaphorically used and refers to the principle that every action produces an effect which is "made to cling to a person" and that his deeds will be recorded in a Book and that their effect will be seen on the day of resurrection. "Clinging to the neck" indicates the inseparability of one thing from another, thus establishing the law of cause and effect.
